huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION:
The Zion unit is an area that has had good mule deer production and the population is generally at or over the objective in the management plan.  The unit is also over the general season buck objective of 18-20 bucks per 100 does.  This has resulted in the opportunity to hunt mule deer during this late season muzzleloader hunt to provide opportunity and harvest additional bucks to reach the unit objectives.  

High deer densities can be found across winter range.  The highest densities can be found on the southeastern portion of the unit including areas along and south of SR9 and east of Zion National Park.  Landmark areas include Poverty Flat, Elephant Gap, and the Coral Pink Sand Dunes State Park.  There is no hunting allowed in Zion.  

Substantial numbers of wintering deer may also be found south of Cedar City along I-15, south to the New Harmony exit.  Additionally, good mule deer winter range exists south of Zion National Park on Smith Mesa and the surrounding drainages.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS:
The Zion unit offers substantial truck and ATV access.  Cellular phone coverage within this hunt boundary can be spotty.  

The biologist suggests hand held radios and even a "Spot Tracker" type of satellite messaging device for safety.  Make sure someone knows where you plan to camp and when you will return.
Plan on bringing plenty of water, fuel, good tires with extra spares, and plenty of ice.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for rain, lightning, as well as winter conditions.  Storms can cause muddy road conditions and flash floods in this region.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 69.2~19000~14850~18–20~18.5~~~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Location of harvest:  The majority of hunters tend to hunt on public lands managed by the BLM and SITLA.  Typically hunters are successful if they are certain where public lands and access roads exist within the hunt boundary, so study some property boundary maps.  A 4WD or ATV will be useful to for access at this time of year.  

Migration Patterns:  
The migratory segments of this population may begin their fall movements in late September and October.  Migration from summer ranges may be dependent on fall storms and weather conditions.  Most deer will be on winter range during this hunt.  

Scouting Tips:
A good spotting scope and binoculars will be helpful. Scouting is most effective right before the hunt opens since deer are still moving and will be in or close to the rut.  I would plan on covering a lot of ground to locate public lands and access points.   

Behavior:  Mule deer should be in rut and preparing for winter during this hunt and therefore may be found in large groups.  They should be in a high level of activity feeding and in rutting behaviors.

huntMaster.SPECIAL_PROVISIONS:
This is a Limited-entry hunt that takes place on a General-season unit. You will lose your bonus points if you draw out for this hunt.
Hunters are encouraged to use nonlead ammunition on this unit in an effort to help restore endangered California condors. Any legal weapon and muzzleloader permit holders for this unit are eligible to receive a free box of nonlead ammunition and entry in a prize drawing. For details please visit the Utah Hunters Helping Condors webpage.
huntMaster.NOTES:
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: REQUIRED: click here or call 1-800-221-0659 to report your harvest. You must report your harvest, even if you did not take an animal, within 30 days of the season end date that is printed on your permit; failure to do so may result in you not being able to apply for big game species in subsequent years. Submitting teeth or other biological samples from your animal, or having your animal checked by a DWR representative or CWMU operator does NOT fulfill your mandatory harvest reporting requirement.

huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: Please direct all questions regarding maps and camping regulations to the Kanab and St George BLM Field Offices.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: BLM: Kanab, St George, Cedar City
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM and SITLA and regulations are covered in their Travel Management Plans.  Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the Kanab and St George BLM Field Office.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: This unit is largely private land.  Make sure you have written permission before entering private land.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Iron, Kane and Washington counties—Boundary begins at the Utah-Arizona state line and I-15; north on I-15 to SR-14; east on SR-14 to US-89; south on US-89 to US-89A; south on US-89A to the Utah-Arizona state line; west on this state line to I-15. This hunt is comprised of all or largely private property. Excludes Zion National Park. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LANDS WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Cedar City, Kanab, Panguitch, Saint George. Boundary questions? Call the Cedar City office, 435-865-6100.
